questionListItems.title: What will a student be evaluated on for admission via DSA?

answer.body: To find out more, visit https://www.rgs.edu.sg/admissions/Admission-to-RGS/via-DSA/

questionListItems.title: Can a student who is currently in a lower level (e.g. Primary 5) be considered for the DSA?

answer.body: No, admission to Secondary One is only for students who have completed Primary 6 or its equivalent.

questionListItems.title: Can a student apply to more than one school?

answer.body: Yes, she many apply to more than one school that offers admissions via DSA, up to a maximum of three schools. The conditions of eligibility (e.g. different sports), selection process and criteria may vary from school to school.

questionListItems.title: Does a student who applies through DSA have to participate in the centralised Secondary One Posting Exercise?

answer.body:
Once she has been offered a place in her choice school and has accepted the offer, she will not take part in the centralised Secondary One Posting Exercise as she would have been deemed to have secured a place in her choice school.

A very important point to note is that once she has accepted a place in the school of her choice via DSA, she cannot transfer out of the school even after the PSLE results have been released. She may have done better than expected but she must remain committed tot he DSA school in which she has accepted a place. In the same way, the DSA school is committed to its offer of a place to the student so long as she qualifies for secondary education in the 'Express stream'. Applications for a transfer will only be considered if there are extenuating circumstances that prevent a student from fulfilling her DSA commitment after she has accepted a place (e.g. a permanent injury that she sustained after accepting a place in her choice DSA school via a sport, and where it is medically deemed that she cannot fulfil her commitment to play the sport after that).

questionListItems.title: When will the PSLE results be released?
When does a student need to choose her secondary schools?

answer.body: Eligible students will receive Secondary 1 Option Forms to select secondary schools when they collect their PSLE results slips. Students should discuss their secondary school choices with their parents before they complete the S1 Option Forms. Students will be required to submit their Option Forms through the Ministry of Education's S1 Posting website at www.moe.gov.sg/s1-posting or through their primary schools within the next seven calendar days from the release of the PSLE results.

questionListItems.title: When will students know their posting results?

answer.body: Students will know their posting results in late December.

questionListItems.title: How can students find out more about any Financial Assistance Schemes that MOE or the school might have for Secondary 1 students?

answer.body: Students can check the MOE website and also contact rgs_studentservices@schools.gov.sg for all information regarding the financial assistance schemes available.

questionListItems.title: What is the new PSLE scoring system and how does it affect a student's school choices?

answer.body: Students can check the MOE website https://www.moe.gov.sg/microsites/psle-fsbb/psle/main.html and https://www.moe.gov.sg/microsites/psle-fsbb/psle/new-psle-scoring-system.html for more information on the new PSLE scoring system and how it affects their school choices.

questionListItems.title: When did RGS move to 2 Braddell Rise?

answer.body: RGS moved to 2 Braddell Rise on 21 October 2019.

questionListItems.title: Why did RGS move to the Braddell site?

answer.body:
This site allows for the holistic development of our students and the deepening of engagement and partnership with the community. RGS and RI are also in close proximity, and hence better able to realise the goals of the Raffles Programme.

 

Our learning spaces are student-focused, environmentally friendly, and inclusive of the community around us. These learning spaces support the unique and distinctive character of RGS and encourage intellectual discourse, innovation, sports, arts, and leadership development. For example:

 

  • Performing Arts Centre allows students to deepen their appreciation of the arts and express themselves in creative ways to collaborate with others beyond the school to forge a more cohesive community.

  • Innovation Hub, comprising the Keppel Sandbox, well-equipped science labs, research labs, makerspace and other special rooms, enables students to acquire computing and technological skills, think outside the box, and bring their creative ideas into reality.

  • Hong Leong Foundation Filiae Centre offers life coaching, art therapy, life skills workshops, and platforms for student expression, on top of existing provisions such as counselling, leadership development, and student administrative services.

questionListItems.title: How does RGS plan to deepen engagement and partnership with the community?

answer.body:
Since 2019, we have partnered neighbouring primary schools and Social Service Agencies (SSAs) in an engagement and partnership initiative called Triple C (Care, Collaboration, Community), where RGS students mentor primary school students in service learning projects with the SSAs.

RGS is currently partnering with two primary schools - First Toa Payoh Primary School and Kheng Cheng School, and two SSAs - Xin Yuan Community Care and Lions Befrienders for the Triple C Programme. 

In addition, we plan to include the community in suitable school programmes as well as share school facilities in due time.

questionListItems.title: Will RGS be increasing its enrolment with the completion of the larger campus?

answer.body: RGS will continue to adhere to MOE's policies and guidelines on student enrolment and intake every year.
